newsitem.title: GERMANY: U.N. Afghan envoy aims to arrange peace talks.
newsitem.headline: U.N. Afghan envoy aims to arrange peace talks.

text.p: United Nations' special envoy to Afghanistan Norbert Holl said on Monday he was trying to arrange peace talks among the country's warring factions.
He told German radio he would visit two more groups after his meeting with the dominant Taleban Islamic militia, which took the capital Kabul on Friday.
"The Afghanistan solution can not be found by talking to Taleban alone," he said. "You have to talk to all the parties."

Speaking from Kabul, Holl said that during a visit to the Taleban's headquarters in the southern Afghan town of Kandahar on Saturday, Taleban leaders said they soon hoped to be ruling the Afghan state from Kabul.
"The decisive thing for me was that I told the Taleban that we, the U.N, wanted to continue and deepen its dialogue with Taleban," Holl, who is German, said in an interview.

"There is no way of getting round the Taleban and the Taleban said it had no intention of pushing the U.N. into a corner but had a keen interest in talking to us too and that it placed great value on U.N. cooperation," Holl said.
Holl said he was given red carpet treatment when he met the leaders of the two-year-old militant Sunni Moslem movement, which grew out of religious schools in refugee camps in Pakistan.
He met Taleban's number two leader Mullah Mohammad Rabbani, whom the media has dubbed Afghanistan's new prime minister, for 2-1/2 hours of talks.

"Taleban said openly they will send their political heavyweights to Kabul, I think it's only a matter of time before they move there...The Taleban is trying to organise itself and to turn the new power structure into the instruments of a normal state," Holl said.

Holl said he raised the issue of the execution of former president Najibullah, who was snatched from the U.N. compound where he had stayed since anti-communist Mujahideen guerrillas took over the capital in April 1992.
Holl described this as a "tragic development" but declined to elaborate on what was said during the talks.
The U.N. Security Council deplored the "brutal execution" of Najibullah, who had been under U.N. protection at the time, late on Saturday.

Taleban captured Kabul with barely a shot fired on Friday and extended its power when its fighters captured the stronghold of former Afghan government military chief Ahmad Shah Masood, north of the Kabul, on Monday.
As soon as it established itself as the ruling force in Kabul, Taleban set up an interim ruling council which vowed to turn Afghanistan into an Islamic state.
